title: SH 114 Irving photos
text: 2018 status: Most photos shown are archival photos due to the construction of managed lanes in 2017. At the east end of the freeway, Texas Stadium was demolished in 2010. In 2020 work started on a $355 million project to complete the interchange at the Texas Stadium site.

images.caption: TX 114 branches off from TX 183 at Texas Stadium. This is the view at the branch point before the implosion of Texas Stadium in April 2010.

imageStatus.note: Texas Stadium was demolished in 2010 and expansion of this interchange at SH 183 began in 2015. In 2020 work began on the $355 million final phase of the interchange project.

images.caption: A closer view of the sign. The sign has been modified in 2015 to have an electronic message board.

imageStatus.note: Texas Stadium was demolished in 2010. The sign has been modified.

images.caption: View of Texas Stadium from TX 114
In September 2020 work was nearing completion on the new "signature" bridge at the Texas Stadium site.
The truss beam will be positioned in the H-shaped support. The red towers appear to be needed for the placement process.
The wide sidewalk includes a sun shade.
This view shows the completed bridge in June 2021. However, the bridge was not yet open or accessible to vehicles or pedestrians.

View of the original freeway, looking west toward the Loop 12 freeway ahead. At the time of this photo, all connections to Loop 12 were made via frontage roads. In October 2008 a $224 million construction contract was awarded to widen the freeway ahead to Riverside/Rochelle to 8 regular lanes and 4 managed lanes, with two new direct connection ramps to Loop 12.  The project was finished in July 2012. However, most of the new pavement is unused because the adjacent sections of freeway have not been widened. In 2017 managed lanes were added to the freeway in the foreground.

imageStatus.note: Managed lanes have been added, and the interchange at SH 114 has been rebuilt with two new ramps added.

images.caption: SH 114 west of Loop 12. This view shows the widened section of SH 114, with enough pavement for 8 regular lanes and 4 managed lanes. The widening was completed in July 2012. In 2015 only 5 lanes were used because adjacent sections have not been widenend. Around 2017 the central managed lanes began to be used.

imageStatus.note: The central managed lanes are being used.

images.caption: SH 114 west of Loop 12. This view shows the central the managed lanes which were unused for several years.

imageStatus.note: The central managed lanes are being used.

images.caption: This view shows the DART light rail station on the north side of the freeway west of Loop 12.
The original freeway, looking west, west of Loop 12. The Las Colinas development is just ahead.

imageStatus.note: In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: Original freeway, looking northwest at Riverside-Rochelle

imageStatus.note: In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: The original freeway looking northwest at Wingren

imageStatus.note: In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: The original freeway looking west, west of O'Connor

imageStatus.note: In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: The original freeway looking westbound near Colwell. Here the freeway merges with the original TX 114 alignment (now Northwest Highway).

imageStatus.note: A bridge for the DART light rail was built across this intersection. In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: The original freeway looking west at Walnut Hill

imageStatus.note: In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: Looking west along the eastbound frontage road at Walnut Hill, showing the original freeway on the right side.

imageStatus.note: In 2017 two managed lanes were added in the freeway median.

images.caption: Looking west at MacArthur, showing the original freeway. The intersection with 161-Toll can be seen in the distance. Connections are made via the frontage roads. Two orphan piers for a future connection ramp are visible.

imageStatus.note: In 2017 one managed lane was added in the freeway median.

images.caption: Near Belt Line, looking west showing the original freeway. Here we can see that the frontage road ahead has not yet been built, but the design obviously anticipates its construction in the future.

imageStatus.note: In 2017 one managed lane was added in the freeway median.

images.caption: Looking westbound from the Belt Line overpass.

imageStatus.note: In 2017 a westbound managed lane was added.

images.caption: Looking west at Freeport Parkway, with TX 121 (the entrance to DFW Airport) just ahead.

imageStatus.note: In 2017 a westbound managed lane was added.
